Waiting Period.content: WAITING PERIOD: For employees in an eligible group on or before December 1, 2015:    First of the month coincident with or next following 30 days of continuous active employment For employees entering an eligible group after December 1, 2015:  First of the month coincident with or next following 30 days of continuous active employment

qa_pairs.question: What is the waiting period for employees in an eligible group who started before December 1, 2015?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page 5, the waiting period for employees in an eligible group on or before December 1, 2015 is the first of the month coincident with or next following 30 days of continuous active employment.

qa_pairs.question: What is the waiting period for employees entering an eligible group after December 1, 2015?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page 5, the waiting period for employees entering an eligible group after December 1, 2015 is also the first of the month coincident with or next following 30 days of continuous active employment.

qa_pairs.question: If an employee's employment ends and they are rehired within 12 months, what happens to their waiting period?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page 10, if an employee's employment ends and they are rehired within 12 months, their previous work while in an eligible group will apply toward the waiting period. The policy provisions apply for all other cases.

Elimination Period.content: ELIMINATION PERIOD: 90 days Benefits begin the day after the elimination period is completed.

qa_pairs.question: What is the duration of the elimination period for a claim under Unum Cert 5019931.pdf?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf pages [5, 13, 14, 15, 20, 21, 28], the elimination period is 90 days.

qa_pairs.question: Are you required to have a 20% or more loss in indexed monthly earnings due to the same injury or sickness to be considered disabled during the elimimation period?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf pages [5, 13, 14, 15, 20, 21, 28], you are not required to have a 20% or more loss in indexed monthly earnings due to the same injury or sickness to be considered disabled during the elimination period.

qa_pairs.question: Can you satisfy your elimination period if you are working while disabled?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf pages [5, 13, 14, 15, 20, 21, 28], if you are working while you are disabled, the days you are disabled will count toward your elimination period.

Elimination Period.content: You must be continuously disabled through your  elimination period . qa_pairs.question: Can you satisfy your elimination period if you are working while disabled?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf pages [5, 13, 14, 15, 20, 21, 28], if you are working while you are disabled, the days you are disabled will count toward your elimination period.

Monthly Earnings.content: 60% of monthly earnings to a maximum benefit of $10,000 per month.

qa_pairs.question: What are the requirements for proof of disability earnings?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page 30, appropriate financial records may be required, which could include income tax returns to substantiate your income as part of the proof of disability earnings.

qa_pairs.question: How is the monthly payment calculated during the elimination period if an individual is disabled for less than a month?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page 31, after the elimination period, if you are disabled for less than 1 month, we will send you 1/30 of your payment for each day of disability.

qa_pairs.question: How is the monthly payment calculated during the disability period?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page 28-29, after the elimination period, if you are disabled for more than a month, your monthly payment will be based on your percentage of lost earnings as calculated by multiplying your monthly payment by this percentage of lost earnings; - the end of the maximum period of payment; -  the date you are eligible to receive benefits under Unum's Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance program; - the date you fail to submit proof of continuing disability; or after 12 months of payments if considered to reside outside United States or Canada. You will be considered to reside outside these countries when you have been outside the following schedule: for the first year, by an increase of 4% based on the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers (CPI-U) as a result of this adjustment will not decrease below your earnings prior to the date your disability benefits begin.

Monthly Earnings.selected_text: "Monthly Earnings" means your average gross monthly income as figured:
Monthly Earnings.content: "Monthly Earnings" means your average gross monthly income as figured: a.  from the income box on your W-2 form which reflects wages, tips and other compensation received from your Employer for the calendar year just prior to your date of disability; or b.  for the period of your employment with your Employer if you did not receive a W- 2 form prior to your date of disability. Average gross monthly income is your total income before taxes.  It is prior to any deductions made for pre-tax contributions to a qualified deferred compensation plan, Section 125 plan, or flexible spending account.  It does not include income received from car, housing or moving allowances, Employer contributions to a qualified deferred compensation plan, or income received from sources other than your Employer.

Monthly Earnings.selected_text: exceed 100% of indexed monthly earnings.
Monthly Earnings.content: During the first 12 months of payments, while working, your monthly payment will not be reduced as long as disability earnings plus the gross disability payment does not exceed 100% of indexed monthly earnings. 1.  Add your monthly disability earnings to your gross disability payment. 2.  Compare the answer in Item 1 to your indexed monthly earnings. If the answer from Item 1 is less than or equal to 100% of your indexed monthly earnings, Unum will not further reduce your monthly payment. If the answer from Item 1 is more than 100% of your indexed monthly earnings, Unum will subtract the amount over 100% from your monthly payment. After 12 months of payments, while working, you will receive payments based on the percentage of income you are losing due to your disability. 1.  Subtract your disability earnings from your indexed monthly earnings. 2.  Divide the answer in Item 1 by your indexed monthly earnings.  This is your percentage of lost earnings. 3.  Multiply your monthly payment by the answer in Item 2. This is the amount Unum will pay you each month. As part of your proof of disability earnings, we can require that you send us appropriate financial records, which may include income tax returns, which we believe are necessary to substantiate your income. qa_pairs.question: How is the monthly payment calculated during the disability period?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page 28-29, after the elimination period, if you are disabled for more than a month, your monthly payment will be based on your percentage of lost earnings as calculated by multiplying your monthly payment by this percentage of lost earnings; - the end of the maximum period of payment; -  the date you are eligible to receive benefits under Unum's Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance program; - the date you fail to submit proof of continuing disability; or after 12 months of payments if considered to reside outside United States or Canada. You will be considered to reside outside these countries when you have been outside the following schedule: for the first year, by an increase of 4% based on the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers (CPI-U) as a result of this adjustment will not decrease below your earnings prior to the date your disability benefits begin.

Monthly Earnings.selected_text: 2.  Compare the answer in Item 1 to your indexed monthly earnings.
Monthly Earnings.content: 1.  Add your monthly disability earnings to your gross disability payment. 2.  Compare the answer in Item 1 to your indexed monthly earnings. If the answer from Item 1 is less than or equal to 100% of your indexed monthly earnings, Unum will not further reduce your monthly payment. If the answer from Item 1 is more than 100% of your indexed monthly earnings, Unum will subtract the amount over 100% from your monthly payment. After 12 months of payments, while working, you will receive payments based on the percentage of income you are losing due to your disability. 1.  Subtract your disability earnings from your indexed monthly earnings. 2.  Divide the answer in Item 1 by your indexed monthly earnings.  This is your percentage of lost earnings. 3.  Multiply your monthly payment by the answer in Item 2. This is the amount Unum will pay you each month. As part of your proof of disability earnings, we can require that you send us appropriate financial records, which may include income tax returns, which we believe are necessary to substantiate your income. After the elimination period, if you are disabled for less than 1 month, we will send you 1/30 of your payment for each day of disability.

Monthly Earnings.selected_text: INDEXED MONTHLY EARNINGS  means your monthly earnings adjusted on each
Monthly Earnings.content: INDEXED MONTHLY EARNINGS  means your monthly earnings adjusted on each anniversary of benefit payments by the lesser of 10% or the current annual percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index.  Your indexed monthly earnings may increase or remain the same, but will never decrease. The Consumer Price Index (CPI-U) is published by the U.S. Department of Labor. Unum reserves the right to use some other similar measurement if the Department of Labor changes or stops publishing the CPI-U. Indexing is only used as a factor in the determination of the percentage of lost earnings while you are disabled and working and in the determination of gainful occupation.

Monthly Earnings.selected_text: payments to you by your Employer of all or part of your monthly earnings, after you
Monthly Earnings.content: SALARY CONTINUATION OR ACCUMULATED SICK LEAVE  means continued payments to you by your Employer of all or part of your monthly earnings, after you become disabled as defined by the Policy.  This continued payment must be part of an established plan maintained by your Employer for the benefit of all employees covered under the Policy.  Salary continuation or accumulated sick leave does not include compensation paid to you by your Employer for work you actually perform after your disability begins.  Such compensation is considered disability earnings, and would be taken into account in calculating your monthly payment.

qa_pairs.question: What is the survivor benefit amount provided by Unum if a policyholder dies?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page [6], the survivor benefit paid to an eligible survivor upon death is equal to 3 months of the policyholder's gross disability payment.

qa_pairs.question: When can a terminally ill policyholder receive the survivor benefit prior to their death?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page [6], if a policyholder has been diagnosed as terminally ill, they may receive the 3 month survivor benefit prior to their death.

qa_pairs.question: What happens to the 3 month survivor benefit if a policyholder elects to receive it before their death?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page [6], if a policyholder elects to receive the 3 month survivor benefit prior to their death, no additional 3 month survivor benefit will be payable upon their death. Furthermore, it is mentioned on page [22] that any overpayment which may exist on the claim will first be applied to the survivor benefit before it is paid out.

qa_pairs.question: Is a Work Life Assistance Program available with the plan as per Unum Cert 5019931.pdf?
qa_pairs.answer: Yes, based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page [6, 26], you and your dependents are provided access to a Work Life Assistance Program designed to help with daily living issues.

qa_pairs.question: How can one access this program?
qa_pairs.answer: The program can be accessed by a 1-800 telephone number available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week or online through a website. Information about this program can be obtained through your plan administrator.

qa_pairs.question: What kind of issues can the Work Life Assistance Program help with?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page [6, 26], the Work Life Assistance Program can help with virtually any personal or professional issue, including finding day care, transportation for an elderly parent, researching colleges for a child, and dealing with workplace stress. It also provides crisis support.

Work Life Assistance Program.selected_text: IS THERE A WORK LIFE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM AVAILABLE WITH THE PLAN?
Work Life Assistance Program.content: IS THERE A WORK LIFE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM AVAILABLE WITH THE PLAN? We do provide you and your dependents access to a work life assistance program designed to assist you with problems of daily living. You can call and request assistance for virtually any personal or professional issue, from helping find a day care or transportation for an elderly parent, to researching possible colleges for a child, to helping to deal with the stress of the workplace.  This work life program is available for everyday issues as well as crisis support. This service is also available to your Employer. This program can be accessed by a 1-800 telephone number available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week or online through a website. Information about this program can be obtained through your plan administrator.

qa_pairs.question: What defines the end of coverage for a policy or plan according to Unum Cert 5019931.pdf?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page [11, 14, 16, 31, 33], the end of coverage can be the date the policy or plan is cancelled, the last day of the period for which you made any required contributions, the last day you are in active employment (except as provided under the covered layoff or leave of absence provision), the date you no longer are in an eligible group, or the date your eligible group is no longer covered.

qa_pairs.question: How does Unum determine average gross monthly income?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page [11, 14, 16, 31, 33], average gross monthly income is your total income before taxes. It includes pre-tax contributions to a qualified deferred compensation plan, Section 125 plan, or flexible spending account, but excludes income received from car, housing or moving allowances, Employer contributions to a qualified deferred compensation plan, and income received from sources other than your Employer.

qa_pairs.question: What are retirement payments according to Unum Cert 5019931.pdf?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page [11, 14, 16, 31, 33], retirement payments are those benefits which are based on your Employer's contribution to the retirement plan. Disability benefits which reduce the retirement benefit under the plan will also be considered as a retirement benefit. Regardless of how the retirement funds from the retirement plan are distributed, Unum will consider your and your Employer's contributions to be distributed simultaneously throughout your lifetime. Retirement payments do not include amounts rolled over or transferred to any eligible retirement plan, and they exclude payments made at the later of age 62 or normal retirement age under your Employer's retirement plan which are attributable to contributions you made on a post tax basis to the system.

qa_pairs.question: What are retirement payments according to Unum Cert 5019931.pdf?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page [11, 14, 16, 31, 33], retirement payments are those benefits which are based on your Employer's contribution to the retirement plan. Mental Illness Limitation.selected_text: Unum will not apply the mental illness limitation to dementia if it is a result of:
Mental Illness Limitation.content: Unum will not apply the mental illness limitation to dementia if it is a result of: -  stroke; -  trauma; -  viral infection; -  Alzheimer's disease; or -  other conditions not listed which are not usually treated by a mental health provider or other qualified provider using psychotherapy, psychotropic drugs, or other similar methods of treatment.

qa_pairs.question: What mental illness limitation exceptions does Unum have for dementia?
qa_pairs.answer: Unum will not apply the mental illness limitation to dementia if it is a result of stroke, trauma, viral infection, Alzheimer's disease, or other conditions not listed which are not usually treated by a mental health provider or other qualified provider using psychotherapy, psychotropic drugs, or other similar methods of treatment. [20]

qa_pairs.question: Which specific conditions that cause dementia are excluded from the mental illness limitation?
qa_pairs.answer: Dementia resulting from stroke, trauma, viral infection, Alzheimer's disease, and other conditions not listed which are not usually treated by a mental health provider or other qualified provider using psychotherapy, psychotropic drugs, or other similar methods of treatment are excluded from the mental illness limitation. [20]

qa_pairs.question: How does Unum classify dementia caused by conditions not listed in the policy?
qa_pairs.answer: Dementia caused by conditions not listed in the policy will be evaluated to determine if it is usually treated by a mental health provider or other qualified provider using psychotherapy, psychotropic drugs, or other similar methods of treatment. If it is not, then the mental illness limitation will not apply. [20]

Pre-existing Condition.content: -  intentionally self-inflicted injuries. -  active participation in a riot. -  loss of a professional license, occupational license or certification. -  commission of a crime for which you have been convicted. -  pre-existing condition. Your plan will not cover a disability due to war, declared or undeclared, or any act of war. Unum will not pay a benefit for any period of disability during which you are incarcerated.

qa_pairs.question: What is considered a pre-existing condition according to the Unum Cert 5019931.pdf?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page 20, a pre-existing condition is when you received medical treatment, consultation, care or services including diagnostic measures, or took prescribed drugs or medicines in the 3 months just prior to your effective date of coverage, and if the disability begins in the first 12 months after your effective date of coverage.

qa_pairs.question: How does Unum handle a disability claim due to a pre-existing condition when an employer changes insurance carriers to Unum?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page 23, if you were in active employment and insured under the plan on its effective date, and insured by the prior policy at the time of change, Unum may send a payment for your disability claim due to a pre-existing condition provided that you satisfy either the Unum plan's or the prior carrier's plan's pre-existing condition provision.

qa_pairs.question: What happens if an individual does not satisfy both conditions mentioned in regards to a pre-existing condition when changing insurance carriers?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page 23, if you do not satisfy either the Unum plan's or the prior carrier's plan's pre-existing condition provision, Unum will not make any payments for your disability claim due to a pre-existing condition.

Carrier.content: WHAT IF YOU ARE NOT IN ACTIVE EMPLOYMENT WHEN YOUR EMPLOYER CHANGES INSURANCE CARRIERS TO UNUM? (Continuity of Coverage)

qa_pairs.question: What happens if an individual is not in active employment when their employer changes insurance carriers to Unum, under the Continuity of Coverage policy?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf pages 22-23, your payment will be limited to the amount that would have been paid by the prior carrier. Unum will reduce your payment by any amount for which your prior carrier is liable.

qa_pairs.question: What if an individual has a disability due to a pre-existing condition when their employer changes insurance carriers to Unum, under the Continuity of Coverage policy?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf pages 22-23, Unum may send a payment if your disability results from a pre-existing condition. However, this will only happen if either the Unum plan or the prior carrier's plan would have paid benefits had their respective policies remained in force. If you do not meet these criteria, Unum will not make any payments.

qa_pairs.question: How does Unum administer a claim for an individual with a disability due to a pre-existing condition if they only satisfy one of the conditions mentioned in the policy?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf pages 22-23, if you only satisfy Item 2 (i.e., the prior carrier's plan would have paid benefits had it remained in force), Unum will administer your claim according to the Unum plan provisions. If you satisfy both conditions, payments will be determined according to the Unum plan provisions.

Worksite Modification.content: A worksite modification might be what is needed to allow you to perform the material and substantial duties of your regular occupation with your Employer.  One of our designated professionals will assist you and your Employer to identify a modification we agree is likely to help you remain at work or return to work. qa_pairs.question: What is the purpose of a worksite modification?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page [26], a worksite modification might be what is needed to allow an individual to perform the material and substantial duties of their regular occupation with their Employer.

qa_pairs.question: How does Unum assist in the process of worksite modification?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page [26], one of Unum's designated professionals will assist you and your Employer to identify a modification that is likely to help you remain at work or return to work.

qa_pairs.question: What are the conditions for the agreement regarding worksite modification?
qa_pairs.answer: Based on Unum Cert 5019931.pdf page [26], when there is an agreement on a worksite modification, it must be in writing and must be signed by you, your Employer, and Unum. When this occurs, Unum will reimburse your Employer for the cost of the modification.
